text: Papyrus Oxyrhynchus 1007 (LXXP.Oxy.VII.1007; P.Oxy. VII 1007; P.Lond.Lit. 199; TM 61956; LDAB 3113; Rahlfs 907) is a fragment of a Septuagint manuscript. It was discovered in Oxyrhynchus, modern El-Bahnasa, Egypt, and has been palaeographically dated to the 3rd century CE. The manuscript is currently housed in the department of manuscripts at the British Library, London (Inv. 2047). == Description == The manuscript contains sections of the Book of Genesis (2:7-9, 2:16-19 recto; 2:23-3:1, 3:6-8 verso), with the Name of God "abbreviated by doubling the initial yod, written with in the shape of a z with a horizontal line through the middle, and carried unbroken through both characters ~~zz~~." == History == The manuscript was published in The Oxyrhynchus Papyri, part VII, edited and translated by Arthur S. Hunt, London, 1910, pages 1 and 2. It was catalogued with the number 907 in the list of manuscripts of the Septuagint as classified by Alfred Rahlfs, and also signed as Van Haelst. It is given the identification 3113 on the Leuven Database of Ancient Books. == References == == Other websites == * Description of P. LXX Oxyrhynchus 1007 * Image P. LXX Oxyrhynchus 1007 * The Oxyrhynchus Papyri, Part 7 online at Archive.org Category:3rd-century biblical manuscripts Category:Septuagint manuscripts
title: Papyrus Oxyrhynchus 1007
